column27: social media is a very important thing in our daily lives. People can't even think about a second without social media. Because of their busy life
column28: people depend more on social media for information
column29: thus increasing its popularity. Social media can be considered as a two-sided coin having its own advantage and disadvantage. These media help people to connect with their family or friends around the world. But the other side of the social media has many disadvantages. It can be considered as the cause of many problems in our society. One such major issue is the fake news. People were unable to distinguish the true and fake news and also about the credibility of the news and the news provider. They blindly believe the news without knowing the truth and they share the news with others. As a result
column30: the fake news spread faster than the true news. By this
column31: many people and organizations get affected. So
column32: in a world of increasing fake news
column33: a fake news detection system is an essential thing. This project deals with fake news. The system is a Webapp named ALIKAH- a clickbait and fake news detection system. It is just like social media network where the news providers can provide the news. This system distinguishes the fake and true news among the news provided in the Alikah system. There are three modules in this system-the admin
column34: news providers and the users. Admin manages and monitors the system and its functionalities. News providers can provide the news to this system after getting permission from the admin and the user can view
column37: report and subscribe to the news and the news provider. Neural network is used as the classifier. This system detects the fake news by checking the credibility of the news provider
column38: monitoring the comments and also by checking the relation of the heading and content of the news provided. It also helps to detect the fake news spreading on other social media like Facebook
column39: by using its heading and content. This system definitely will be a beneficiary to the people and organizations which get affected by the news and also help to find the providers of these news. © 2019 IEEE.""

column7: This exploratory study examines how fake news differs from real news in terms of propagation pattern on social media. It analyzed 40 news (20 fake news + 20 real news) surrounding the 2016 US presidential election that emerged on Twitter. Three major observations were made. First
column8: fake news appeared to be posted more than real news. Second
column10: the growing volume of tweets for fake news indicated its sustainable propagation to achieve a wider reach. Third
column11: the tweet volume of real news dropped drastically after the first day. However
column12: it was not true for fake news. The observations are discussed in light of the related literature. © 2019 IEEE.""

column1: Abad C.S.,"The first fake news of History [La primera fake news de la historia]",2019,"Historia y Comunicacion Social",1,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85078180952&doi=10.5209%2fhics.66268&partnerID=40&md5=44c7c2180ca078d6944731fe35055624","Centro Universitario Villanueva, Spain","Abad, C.S., Centro Universitario Villanueva, Spain","The first ‘fake news’ of Contemporary History was published by the New York newspaper The Sun in 1835 and dealt about beings that inhabited the Moon. The news caused a huge impact in the US due to three factors: the appearance of high-capacity presses, the fall in the price of newspapers (the penny press), and the arrival of new transportation means that exceeded the speed of the horses for the first time in history: trains and steamboats. All these factors helped to disseminate false and sensationalist information on a large scale under the guise of true news. Today this is what we call “fake news”. © 2019 Universidad Complutense de Madrid. All rights reserved.","Fake news; Great moon hoax; Internet; The sun;" Trump""

column12: The rampant spread of fake news on social media has skyrocketed over the years. Fake news has become a notorious devil affecting the overall demographic of the nation. Its not only regular users who are worried but also the marketers who raised concerns about the impact of fake news on trade. Online sources for news consumption are a double edged sword. Fake news is increasingly becoming a menace to our society. It is typically generated for commercial interests to attract viewers and also to collect advertising revenue. However
column13: media giants with potentially malicious agendas have been known to produce fake news in order to influence events and policies around the world. This paper addresses a classifier that can predict whether a piece of news is legit and not just a botched up fact. The proposed model train itself using data sets having headlines of news of multiple years to predict whether a news article is true to its word. The proposed work provides a convenient hassle-free platform for everyone and aims to spread calm by decreasing rumors and misunderstandings in the society. © 2019 IEEE.""

column1: Zimmer F., Reich A.,"What is truth? Fake news and their uncovering by the audience",2018,"Proceedings of the 5th European Conference on Social Media, ECSM 2018",1,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85064620067&partnerID=40&md5=199676d07f21411db60d925a01f13e2d","Heinrich Heine University, Dsseldorf, Germany","Zimmer, F., Heinrich Heine University, Dsseldorf, Germany;" Reich
column7: whether distributed on social media or in the conventional press
column8: carry the risk of being fake news. How to determine the truth (or falseness) of news? Are there exact criteria to distinguish clearly between true and false news? For example
column9: President Trump denunciates everything the critical press says as """"fake news."""" Filter bubbles help the user to stay in their own sense of truth";" algorithms only show them what they are interested in. We provide a systematical analysis of fake news and its content in relation to the truth. In the empirical part of our research
column10: a survey (N=448) in Germanspeaking areas was conducted to investigate how relevant the content versus the source of news is for detecting fake news. Scientific literature about fake news and post-truth was collected and the different truth theories extracted. We interpreted truth and falsehood in the fake news articles according to the truth theories. The theories that were represented the most often are the theory of reflection
column13: and evidence theory of truth. In the survey
column14: four separate groups were formed at random. Each group was presented with four different news (two of them were true
column15: two of them were satire) for which the sources were arbitrarily mixed up. The participants had to discern which news they perceived as being faked. Our take on fake news and its implications for society is that there is no satisfactory answer on what is considered as the truth
column16: because each truth theory can negate the other. The survey showed that the influence of the source is much greater than of the content when deciding if something is perceived as being true. Copyright © The Authors

column1: Viriyavejakul C.,"Analysis of Fake News and the Level of Cognitive Perception of Undergraduate Students in the University in Thailand",2019,"Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85076743424&doi=10.1007%2f978-3-030-35343-8_80&partnerID=40&md5=caa46fcc543dcc5f1210cbd1edc352e1","King Mongkut’s Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand","Viriyavejakul, C., King Mongkut’s Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand","The purpose of this study aimed to study the relationship between fake news and the cognitive perception of online sources of Thai public. With intensified use in a world of IT devices, more knowledge is available. The Thai trait of belief in all printed or published media must be changed for fake news to be discerned by users. A survey was made by 500 online questionnaires found that much news on social media outlets was a scam, incite feelings against or for a group of people. In Thailand, the general person easily believes in media platform because they are written, and supported by pictures and testimonial information. Fake news was used (1) online items and trusted as things printed are true (2) people express good or bad feelings for a public person, Thai people must for educated form early to doubt. © Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2019.","Cognitive perception; Fake news; Platform;" Undergraduate students""

column1: Sindermann C., Cooper A., Montag C.,"A short review on susceptibility to falling for fake political news",2020,"Current Opinion in Psychology",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85085957493&doi=10.1016%2fj.copsyc.2020.03.014&partnerID=40&md5=fea791ac4d2a75c04b1c24ec6e3ac0c9","Department of Molecular Psychology, Institute of Psychology and Education, Ulm University, Ulm, 89081, Germany;" Department of Psychology
column25: This review discusses recent findings on susceptibility to falling for fake news in political contexts. In relation to political attitudes and analytical thinking
column26: we find that individuals tend to overrate the accuracy of true and fake political news that are consistent with their own political attitudes. This tendency
column28: does not seem to be explained by motivated reasoning. This is supported by findings showing that analytical thinking and deliberation are negatively related to susceptibility to falling for fake news
column29: regardless of whether they are consistent or inconsistent with one's political attitudes. We suggest that future works should aim at i) examining how
column31: news consumption habits relate to susceptibility to falling for fake news and ii) implementing other
column32: more externally valid fake news tests. © 2020 Elsevier Ltd""

column1: Shu K., Wang S., Liu H.,"Beyond news contents: The role of social context for fake news detection",2019,"WSDM 2019 - Proceedings of the 12th ACM International Conference on Web Search and Data Mining",35,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85061758760&doi=10.1145%2f3289600.3290994&partnerID=40&md5=d565c6777e0cc37fed37dcc70c532d6a","Arizona State University, United States;" Penn State University
column13: Social media is becoming popular for news consumption due to its fast dissemination
column16: it also enables the wide propagation of fake news
column18: news with intentionally false information. Detecting fake news is an important task
column19: which not only ensures users receive authentic information but also helps maintain a trustworthy news ecosystem. The majority of existing detection algorithms focus on finding clues from news contents
column20: which are generally not effective because fake news is often intentionally written to mislead users by mimicking true news. Therefore
column21: we need to explore auxiliary information to improve detection. The social context during news dissemination process on social media forms the inherent tri-relationship
column25: which has potential to improve fake news detection. For example
column26: partisan-biased publishers are more likely to publish fake news
column27: and low-credible users are more likely to share fake news. In this paper
column28: we study the novel problem of exploiting social context for fake news detection. We propose a tri-relationship embedding framework TriFN
column29: which models publisher-news relations and user-news interactions simultaneously for fake news classification. We conduct experiments on two real-world datasets
column30: which demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly outperforms other baseline methods for fake news detection. © 2019 Association for Computing Machinery.""

column7: Identification of Fake News is import now a days because it is affecting our social life and opinions. Public misinformation detection is complicated task especially Pakistani media Fake News classification. We have seen Fake News in every aspect of life like politics
column10: entertainment and many more. For identification of fake news
column11: we have done popular news websites scrap and develop our corpus of 344 News articles and labeled it manually Fake or True. We have investigated two feature extraction techniques like Term Frequency (TF) and Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF). Seven different supervised Machine Learning (ML) classification algorithms are used and their results comparison have done. Best performance classifier K Nearest Neighbors (KNN) gives 70% accuracy and logistic regression gives 69% accuracy. Results can improved further by increasing number of articles in corpus. © 2019 IEEE.""

column1: Shu K., Zhou X., Wang S., Zafarani R., Liu H.,"The role of user profiles for fake news detection",2019,"Proceedings of the 2019 IEEE/ACM International Conference on Advances in Social Networks Analysis and Mining, ASONAM 2019",3,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85078868477&doi=10.1145%2f3341161.3342927&partnerID=40&md5=0903a9c53679d6e4e2bd535dff00e9c6","Arizona State University, United States; Penn State University
column20: Consuming news from social media is becoming increasingly popular. Social media appeals to users due to its fast dissemination of information
column23: social media also enables the widespread of fake news. Due to the detrimental societal effects of fake news
column24: detecting fake news has attracted increasing attention. However
column25: the detection performance only using news contents is generally not satisfactory as fake news is written to mimic true news. Thus
column26: there is a need for an in-depth understanding on the relationship between user profiles on social media and fake news. In this paper
column27: we study the problem of understanding and exploiting user profiles on social media for fake news detection. In an attempt to understand connections between user profiles and fake news
column29: we measure users’ sharing behaviors and group representative users who are more likely to share fake and real news";" then
column30: we perform a comparative analysis of explicit and implicit profile features between these user groups
column31: which reveals their potential to help differentiate fake news from real news. To exploit user profile features
column32: we demonstrate the usefulness of these user profile features in a fake news classification task. We further validate the effectiveness of these features through feature importance analysis. The findings of this work lay the foundation for deeper exploration of user profile features of social media and enhance the capabilities for fake news detection. © 2019 Association for Computing Machinery.""

column20: """"fake news. """" The wide distribution of fake news has a considerable negative impact on individuals and society as a whole. Thus
column21: detecting fake news published on the various social media websites has lately become an evolving research area that is drawing great attention. Detecting the widespread fake news over the numerous social media platforms presents new challenges that make the currently deployed algorithms ineffective or not applicable anymore. Basically

column23: which makes it difficult to detect based on news content solely";" consequently

column13: The development and deployment of new technologies have influenced the media environment by enabling quick and effective dissemination of false news via social networks. Several experimental studies have highlighted the role of thinking style
column15: source credibility and other factors when it comes to fake news recognition. Our study makes several contributions to existing knowledge. Web introduce a measure of conspiracy thinking
column16: a comparison between politics and business news recognition
column17: and we investigate the effects of sensationalist headlines on users’ abilities to differentiate between false and true news. 228 university students (203 completed the entire survey) from three departments (Humanities
column19: and Economics) took part in an online experiment. The results of a regression analysis demonstrate that double-checking of news online has a significant effect on individuals’ overall ability of differentiating between true and false news. Thinking styles
column21: and such control variables as age and gender have no significant effect on the overall level of accuracy. We also discuss the effects of different factors responsible for the accuracy of fake news recognition in business and political news

column1: Abu Salem F.K., Al Feel R., Elbassuoni S., Jaber M., Farah M.,"FA-KES: A fake news dataset around the Syrian War",2019,"Proceedings of the 13th International Conference on Web and Social Media, ICWSM 2019",4,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85070366169&partnerID=40&md5=1a0a5accc604f52a17c808b1e1193161","Computer Science Department, American University of Beirut, Lebanon;" Sociology and Anthropology Department
column25: Most currently available fake news datasets revolve around US politics
column26: entrainment news or satire. They are typically scraped from fact-checking websites
column27: where the articles are labeled by human experts. In this paper
column29: a fake news dataset around the Syrian war. Given the specific nature of news reporting on incidents of wars and the lack of available sources from which manually-labeled news articles can be scraped
column30: we believe a fake news dataset specifically constructed for this domain is crucial. To ensure a balanced dataset that covers the many facets of the Syrian war
column31: our dataset consists of news articles from several media outlets representing mobilisation press
column33: and diverse print media. To avoid the difficult and often-subjective task of manually labeling news articles as true or fake
column34: we employ a semi-supervised fact-checking approach to label the news articles in our dataset. With the help of crowdsourcing
column35: human contributors are prompted to extract specific and easy-to-extract information that helps match a given article to information representing “ground truth” obtained from the Syrian Violations Documentation Center. The information extracted is then used to cluster the articles into two separate sets using unsupervised machine learning. The result is a carefully annotated dataset consisting of 804 articles labeled as true or fake and that is ideal for training machine learning models to predict the credibility of news articles. Our dataset is publicly available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.2607278. Although our dataset is focused on the Syrian crisis
column36: it can be used to train machine learning models to detect fake news in other related domains. Moreover
column37: the framework we used to obtain the dataset is general enough to be used to build other fake news datasets around military conflicts
column38: provided there is some corresponding ground-truth available. Copyright © 2019
column39: Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (www.aaai.org). All rights reserved.""

column1: Omezi N., Jahankhani H.,"Proposed forensic guidelines for the investigation of fake news",2020,"Advanced Sciences and Technologies for Security Applications",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85090511835&doi=10.1007%2f978-3-030-50613-1_11&partnerID=40&md5=7afdf9171c174fa6440f88f970b5a822","Northumbria University, London, United Kingdom","Omezi, N., Northumbria University, London, United Kingdom;" Jahankhani
column8: no longer holds true in modern society. Digital media has paved the way for anyone to doctor images and for videos to misrepresent truth. The lines between fact
column11: fabrication and fiction are becoming increasingly blurred as what is termed ‘fake news’ increases in modern day society. A natural consequence of the increase in fake news is the outcry for investigations into misinformation (think Cambridge Analytica). Investigations need to be forensically sound in order for any evidence to hold up in court. This research aims to propose forensic guidelines for the investigation of fake news by researching current fact checking methodologies and determining whether what is currently in place can be aligned to the current ACPO Forensic Guidelines. In order to do this
column12: it first attempts to establish how easily a non-professional fact checker can detect fake news by carrying out a rudimentary fake news quiz. This was then followed by a review of 41 fact checkers to understand their fact checking methodologies and concluded with a basic fact checking experiment to test the veracity of a subset of the reviewed tools. In concluding
column13: fake news investigations can be aligned to the current ACPO forensic guidelines
column15: they will need to be specifically adapted to the three main categories of fake news: images
column16: text and video. © Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2020.""

column8: Online social media plays an important role during real world events such as natural calamities
column10: social movements etc. S ince the social media usage has increased
column11: fake news has grown. The social media is often used by modifying true news or creating fake news to spread misinformation. The creation and distribution of fake news poses major threats i n several respects from a national security point of view. Hence Fake news identification becomes an essential goal for enhancing the trustworthiness of the information shared on online social network. Over the period of time many researcher has used different methods
column13: tools and techniques to identify fake news content from online social networks. The aim of this paper is to review and examine these methodologies
column15: browser extensions and analyze the degree of output in question. In addition
column16: this paper discuss the general approach of fake news detection as well as taxonomy of feature extraction which plays an important role to achieve maximum accuracy with the help of different Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing algorithms. © 2020 IEEE.""

column17: Rapid spreading of misinformation is a growing worldwide concern as it has the capacity to greatly influence individual reputation and societal behavior. The consequences of unchecked spreading of misinformation can not only vary from political to financial but also effect global opinion for a long time. Thus
column18: detecting fake news is important but challenging as the ability to accurately categorize certain information as true or fake is limited even in human. Moreover
column19: fake news are a blend of correct news and false information making accurate classification even more confusing. In this paper
column20: we propose a novel method of multilevel multiclass fake news detection based on relabeling of the dataset and learning iteratively. The proposed method outperforms the benchmark and our experiments indicate that profile of the source of information contributes the most in fake news detection. © 2019 Association for Computing Machinery.""

column1: Prasetyo A., Septianto B.D., Shidik G.F., Fanani A.Z.,"Evaluation of feature extraction TF-IDF in Indonesian hoax news classification",2019,"Proceedings - 2019 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication: Industry 4.0: Retrospect, Prospect, and Challenges, iSemantic 2019",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85074899631&doi=10.1109%2fISEMANTIC.2019.8884291&partnerID=40&md5=780196aac07fb4674c0b38707e11e929","Dian Nuswantoro University, Semarang, Indonesia","Prasetyo, A., Dian Nuswantoro University, Semarang, Indonesia; Septianto
column14: Hoax is information that generally does not exist or not true and dangerous because it can mislead people perception and give an assumption to the news that not truly happen become a truth. In 2016
column15: the election for US president has been held
column17: there are several fake news spread through social media. This incident has to take responsibility for the huge effect on the election result. Therefore
column18: a method for detecting hoax should be developed to prevent the impact of the hoax. The purpose of this research is evaluating several machine learning methods for detecting fake news. The dataset that uses in this research is hoax news collected from Department Communication and Information of Central Java Province (November 20018 and December 2018) and www.turnbackhoax.id (December 2018 until March 2019). The number of documents used for this research is 150 documents consist of 75 documents with true category and 75 documents hoax category. Feature extraction used in this research is TF-IDF algorithm. This research evaluates the performance of several machine learning methods such as MNB
column21: and LSVM in classifying fake news. Base on the test result using 10-fold validation
column22: Logistic classification have the best accuracy with 84.67%. © 2019 IEEE.""

column1: Xie Y., Huang X., Xie X., Jiang S.,"A fake news detection framework using social user graph",2020,"ACM International Conference Proceeding Series",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85089580150&doi=10.1145%2f3404512.3404515&partnerID=40&md5=84cf815cd6468c6905143a9c31cdfbf8","School of Information Science and Technology, Guangdong University of Foreign Studies, Guangzhou, China;" Guangzhou Key Laboratory of Multilingual Intelligent Processing

column24: In the contemporary era of information explosion
column25: all kinds of false and misleading information are flooding our lives
column26: which often impact politics and even our real world. How to detect these potential fake news from massive news texts is of great significance for maintaining social stability. The current fake news detection is mainly researched from supervised classification based on text content. However
column27: it does not always work. Because fake news is often latent
column28: they can imitate true news from the perspective of language style
column30: we need to capture more effective feature information to improve the performance of fake news detection models. For example
column31: the user connections on social networks. At present
column32: some researches have used the characteristics of users in social networks
column33: but the user's characteristic representation is often independent of the task of fake news detection
column34: and some researches ignored the different influences of different users in fake news detection
column35: such as the news released by official news agency is often more authentic. In this paper
column36: we propose a fake news detection framework that makes full use of user characteristics. Firstly
column37: the user's news dissemination behavior was classified based on GraphSage. Then
column38: using multi-head attention to give the user representation that obtained through GraphSage to different weights
column39: which was combined with the news text representation was used for classification. Compared with previous studies
column40: we have achieved the state-of-the-art performance on two real datasets BuzzFeed and PolitiFact
column41: which show the strength of our method. © 2020 ACM.""

column1: Diaz-Garcia J.A., Fernandez-Basso C., Ruiz M.D., Martin-Bautista M.J.,"Mining text patterns over fake and real tweets",2020,"Communications in Computer and Information Science",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85086256842&doi=10.1007%2f978-3-030-50143-3_51&partnerID=40&md5=42ae2a483ade318b3a6ba11e4d6d3d93","Department of Computer Science and A.I., University of Granada, Granada, Spain;" Department of Statistics and O.R.

column26: With the exponential growth of users and user-generated content present on online social networks
column27: fake news and its detection have become a major problem. Through these
column29: aimed for example at trying to change the political orientation of some people. Twitter has become one of the main spreaders of fake news in the network. Therefore
column31: we present a solution based on Text Mining that tries to find which text patterns are related to tweets that refer to fake news and which patterns in the tweets are related to true news. To test and validate the results
column32: the system faces a pre-labelled dataset of fake and real tweets during the U.S. presidential election in 2016. In terms of results interesting patterns are obtained that relate the size and subtle changes of the real news to create fake news. Finally
column33: different ways to visualize the results are provided. © Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2020.""

column1: Hansen C., Hansen C., Simonsen J.G., Larsen B., Alstrup S., Lioma C.,"Factuality Checking in News Headlines with Eye Tracking",2020,"SIGIR 2020 - Proceedings of the 43rd International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85090120754&doi=10.1145%2f3397271.3401221&partnerID=40&md5=5d1603a2f5eeb1ccc6f36d9b4bc1de2c","University of Copenhagen, Copenhagen, Denmark;" Aalborg University
column29: We study whether it is possible to infer if a news headline is true or false using only the movement of the human eyes when reading news headlines. Our study with 55 participants who are eye-tracked when reading 108 news headlines (72 true
column30: 36 false) shows that false headlines receive statistically significantly less visual attention than true headlines. We further build an ensemble learner that predicts news headline factuality using only eye-tracking measurements. Our model yields a mean AUC of 0.688 and is better at detecting false than true headlines. Through a model analysis
column31: we find that eye-tracking 25 users when reading 3-6 headlines is sufficient for our ensemble learner. © 2020 ACM.""

column12: While fake news has been widely reviled as an attack on democracy
column13: less has been written about its threat to interpersonal relationships. Social networks have become increasingly popular for sharing news and as a result have also offered fertile ground for the spread of fake news. This paper considers the impact of the latter on the former
column14: particularly in circumstances where the sharer either does not know or does not suspect that the news they are sharing is fake. This distinction is important because while sharing information and news may be construed as a social good
column15: sharing news that turns out to be fake might negatively impact relationships. How do people react when the news they have shared with the intention of fostering social cohesion turns out to be fake
column16: and as a result damages that cohesion? Based on 12 focus groups
column17: this study examines how social media users react to fake news and how it affects interpersonal relationships between sender and receiver. © 2019

column10: The discussion around the problem of media manipulation has dramatically intensified in recent years
column11: especially in connection with the spread of fake news via the Internet. For example
column14: do not distinguish between fake news and other types of news. However
column15: the problem of fake news is not only related to fabricated media texts
column16: but also reflects the audience's general dissatisfaction with traditional mass media
column18: parties and organizations. From the audience's point of view
column19: the problem of fake news is not limited to false news - it also concerns low-quality journalism
column20: political propaganda and misleading forms of advertising
column21: (dis)trust in public institutions and media agencies. The fact
column22: that in the modern media world unambiguously true and explicitly false information is becoming increasingly rare
column23: further complicates the situation. As a rule
column24: rather sophisticated manipulation techniques that mix reliable and fake information are being used
column25: so there can be no simple judgements regarding the development of mechanisms to ban or remove false media information. Countering disinformation can be based both on technological (computer) algorithms and on qualitative analytics. We also believe that mass media education of the audience can effectively contribute to the development of analytical thinking and media competence of an individual. In particular
column26: the synthesized typology of mass-media manipulation techniques (based on an analysis of scientific research) by the authors of the article can contribute to the development of media competence. © 2020 Academic Publishing House Researcher.""

column1: Bagade A., Pale A., Sheth S., Agarwal M., Chakrabarti S., Chebrolu K., Sudarshan S.,"The Kauwa-Kaate fake news detection system: DemO",2020,"ACM International Conference Proceeding Series",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85078437341&doi=10.1145%2f3371158.3371402&partnerID=40&md5=df79fd8583e51dfeb70adbba69efa786","IIT Bombay, India;" CMU""
column25: Fake news spread via social media is a major problem today. It is not easy with current-generation tools to check if a particular article is genuine or contains fake news. While there are many Web sites today that debunk viral fake news
column26: checking if a particular article has been debunked or is true is not easy for an end-user. Search engines like Google do not make it easy to check a complete article since they limit the number of query keywords. In this paper
column27: we outline the architecture of the Kauwa-Kaate system for fact-checking articles. Queried articles are searched against articles crawled from fact-checking sites
column28: as well as against articles crawled from trusted news sites. Our system supports querying based on text as well as on images and video";" the latter features are very important since many fake news articles are based on images and videos. We also describe the user interfaces which we will use to demonstrate the Kauwa-Kaate system. © 2020 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).""

column38: This paper addresses the problem of fake news detection. There are many works already in this space";" however

column42: to detecting fake news based on news content using knowledge graphs. In our solutions

column26: The cyberspace news consumption is increasing day by day all over the world. column30: images etc. This model works on processing the text and images together by providing an interactive Application Interface (API)

column33: whether it be satire or malicious hoax. We investigate attitudes to news delivered by social media
column36: by individuals. A survey reveals that two thirds of respondents regularly consumed news via Facebook
column37: and that one third had at some point come across fake news that they initially believed to be true. An analysis task involving news presented via Facebook reveals a diverse range of judgement forming strategies
column38: with participants relying on personal judgements as to plausibility and scepticism around sources and journalistic style. This reflects a shift away from traditional methods of accessing the news

column1: Clayton K., Blair S., Busam J.A., Forstner S., Glance J., Green G., Kawata A., Kovvuri A., Martin J., Morgan E., Sandhu M., Sang R., Scholz-Bright R., Welch A.T., Wolff A.G., Zhou A., Nyhan B.,"Real Solutions for Fake News? Measuring the Effectiveness of General Warnings and Fact-Check Tags in Reducing Belief in False Stories on Social Media",2019,"Political Behavior",33,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85061502088&doi=10.1007%2fs11109-019-09533-0&partnerID=40&md5=8454e4df888603d991fa2c56f142916a","Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH, United States;" University of Michigan
column91: Social media has increasingly enabled “fake news” to circulate widely
column92: most notably during the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign. These intentionally false or misleading stories threaten the democratic goal of a well-informed electorate. This study evaluates the effectiveness of strategies that could be used by Facebook and other social media to counter false stories. Results from a pre-registered experiment indicate that false headlines are perceived as less accurate when people receive a general warning about misleading information on social media or when specific headlines are accompanied by a “Disputed” or “Rated false” tag. Though the magnitudes of these effects are relatively modest
column93: they generally do not vary by whether headlines were congenial to respondents’ political views. In addition
column94: we find that adding a “Rated false” tag to an article headline lowers its perceived accuracy more than adding a “Disputed” tag (Facebook’s original approach) relative to a control condition. Finally
column95: though exposure to the “Disputed” or “Rated false” tags did not affect the perceived accuracy of unlabeled false or true headlines
column96: exposure to a general warning decreased belief in the accuracy of true headlines
column97: suggesting the need for further research into how to most effectively counter false news without distorting belief in true information. © 2019

column7: fake news has been incurring many problems to our society. As a result
column8: many researchers have been working on identifying fake news. Most of the fake news detection systems utilize the linguistic feature of the news. However
column9: they have difficulty in sensing highly ambiguous fake news which can be detected only after identifying meaning and latest related information. In this paper
column11: we shall present a new Korean fake news detection system using fact DB which is built and updated by human's direct judgement after collecting obvious facts. Our system receives a proposition
column12: and search the semantically related articles from Fact DB in order to verify whether the given proposition is true or not by comparing the proposition with the related articles in fact DB. To achieve this
column13: we utilize a deep learning model
column14: Bidirectional Multi-Perspective Matching for Natural Language Sentence(BiMPM)
column15: which has demonstrated a good performance for the sentence matching task. However
column16: BiMPM has some limitations in that the longer the length of the input sentence is
column18: and it has difficulty in making an accurate judgement when an unlearned word or relation between words appear. In order to overcome the limitations
column19: we shall propose a new matching technique which exploits article abstraction as well as entity matching set in addition to BiMPM. In our experiment
column20: we shall show that our system improves the whole performance for fake news detection. © 2019 IEEE.""

column23: The easy access and exponential growth of the information available on social media networks has made it intricate to distinguish between false and true information. The easy dissemination of information by way of sharing has added to exponential growth of its falsification. The credibility of social media networks is also at stake where the spreading of fake information is prevalent. Thus
column24: it has become a research challenge to automatically check the information viz a viz its source
column25: content and publisher for categorizing it as false or true. Machine learning has played a vital role in classification of the information although with some limitations. This paper reviews various Machine learning approaches in detection of fake and fabricated news. The limitation of such and approaches and improvisation by way of implementing deep learning is also reviewed. © 2019 IEEE.""

column1: Kalvoda B., Stoick B., Snell N., Straub J.,"Evaluation of algorithms for fake news identification",2019,"Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering",2,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85070064294&doi=10.1117%2f12.2521854&partnerID=40&md5=d94ced882f6fdb44d58206e042836a90","Department of Computer Science, North Dakota State University, Fargo, ND, United States","Kalvoda, B., Department of Computer Science, North Dakota State University, Fargo, ND, United States; Stoick
column21: information is spread quickly throughout communities by means of simple messaging
column23: and social media platforms. Because of the ease of use that these services provide
column24: misinformation has become a common trend. The term 'fake news' has emerged as being a way to refer to all information shared in a manner that is meant to mislead a reader into thinking something is a true statement when it is not. Combating fake news has become a major topic
column25: and many are attempting to find a way of detecting when something is real or made up. In this paper
column26: we look at a database of news articles that have been classified as either real or fake and apply machine learning to automatically determine if something is deliberately misleading. Algorithms have been developed to make judgements
column27: classify articles in a database and judge new articles based on learned knowledge. This model combines multiple factors that may raise or lower confidence in the article being legitimate or illegitimate and provides a single confidence metric. This paper presents the development of these algorithms for assessing articles. It discusses the efficacy of using this approach and compares it to other classification approaches. It then presents the results of using the system to classify numerous presented articles and discusses the sufficiency of system accuracy for multiple applications. Finally
column28: it discusses next steps in the fake news detection project and how these algorithms fit within them. © COPYRIGHT SPIE. Downloading of the abstract is permitted for personal use only.""

column1: Wang L., Fussell S.R.,"More than a click: Exploring college students' decision-making processes in online news sharing",2020,"Proceedings of the ACM on Human-Computer Interaction",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85077772104&doi=10.1145%2f3375189&partnerID=40&md5=2baa49061674935317bbcc1806cda92a","Cornell University, 107 Hoy Rd, Ithaca, United States","Wang, L., Cornell University, 107 Hoy Rd, Ithaca, United States;" Fussell
column7: Fake news can be disseminated on social media platforms due to users' inability to distinguish it from true news as well as the nature of heuristic-driven online sharing. We use in-depth semi-structured interviews with 20 college student social media users to help build a picture of their sharing processes that can help platform designers and operators better combat fake news dissemination. Participants reflected on specific recently shared news pieces
column8: including how the stories attracted attention
column10: and their behavior after sharing. Interview results revealed different cognitive processes people engaged: before
column11: during and after sharing. Before sharing
column12: participants assessed the news content and evaluated the social value of sharing the particular news piece. During sharing
column13: the audience of the post was selected. After sharing
column14: users examined the feedback from others and revisited previous sharing decisions. The study highlights that decisions about news sharing involve a myriad of different considerations throughout different cognitive stages. Based on these findings
column15: we discuss design implications for combating the sharing of fake news. © Copyright is held by the owner/author(s). Publication rights licensed to ACM.""

column8: We explore the use of machine learning techniques to classify a news source for generating unreliable news. Since the advent of the Internet
column9: unreliable news and hoaxes have deceived users. Social media and news outlets are spreading false information to increase the number of viewers or as a part of the psychological competition. In this paper
column10: we present an ensemble classifier using a set of marked true and bogus news articles. Here
column11: the authors develop a classification approach based on text using SVM
column14: Decision Tree as a base learner in Bagging and AdaBoost. The purpose behind the work is to think of an answer that enable the user to classify and filter some of the false material. Accordingly
column15: we show that the best performing classifiers were AdaBoost-LinearSVM and AdaBoost-Random Forest with 90.70% and 80.17% accuracy

column14: The rise of the internet has enabled fake news to reach larger audiences more quickly. As more people turn to social media for news
column15: the accuracy of information on these platforms is especially important. To help enable classification of the accuracy news articles at scale
column16: machine learning models have been developed and trained to recognize fake articles. Previous linguistic work suggests part-of-speech and N-gram frequencies are often different between fake and real articles. To compare how these frequencies relate to the accuracy of the article
column19: was collected for training neural network classifiers. The first model relies solely on part-of-speech frequencies within the body of the text and consistently achieved 82% accuracy. As the proportion of the dataset used for training grew smaller
column21: as expected. The true negative rate
column24: some aspect of the fake articles was readily identifiable
column25: even when the classifier was trained on a limited number of examples. The second model relies on the most commonly occurring N-gram frequencies. The neural nets were trained on N-grams of different length. Interestingly
column26: the accuracy was near 61% for each N-gram size. This suggests some of the same information may be ascertainable across N-grams of different sizes. © COPYRIGHT SPIE. Downloading of the abstract is permitted for personal use only.""

column1: Seo Y., Han S.-S., Jeon Y.-B., Jeong C.-S.,"Fagon: Fake news detection model using grammatical transformation on deep neural network",2019,"KSII Transactions on Internet and Information Systems",1,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85076016496&doi=10.3837%2ftiis.2019.10.008&partnerID=40&md5=1803a1c75f95e84b7a0efe9267bab8bb","Department of Electrical Engineering, Korea University, Seoul, South Korea; Visual Information Processing
column4: South Korea;" Department of Computer Software Engineering
column32: the amount of fake news is increasing more and more by various reasons such as political issues and advertisement exaggeration. However
column33: there have been very few research works on fake news detection
column34: especially which uses grammatical transformation on deep neural network. In this paper
column35: we shall present a new Fake News Detection Model
column36: called FAGON(Fake news detection model using Grammatical transformation On deep Neural network) which determines efficiently if the proposition is true or not for the given article by learning grammatical transformation on neural network. Especially
column37: our model focuses the Korean language. It consists of two modules: sentence generator and classification. The former generates multiple sentences which have the same meaning as the proposition
column38: but with different grammar by training the grammatical transformation. The latter classifies the proposition as true or false by training with vectors generated from each sentence of the article and the multiple sentences obtained from the former model respectively. We shall show that our model is designed to detect fake news effectively by exploiting various grammatical transformation and proper classification structure. Copyright © 2019 KSII.""

column10: Modern political life is heavily dependent and influenced by claims about facts made about participants in a Political System (seen here as sets of agents and organizations that govern a society). Such claims are commonly found in news stories
column15: they may be considered """"true"""" or """"false"""". The decision to act based on a fact contained in a claim is dependent on the agent's trust on the claim
column17: that the fact being stated is indeed """"true"""". In this paper
column18: we propose a framework to describe the trust process
column19: which can serve as a a support for various possible models of content trust. Within this framework
column21: an ontology to describe a Political System
column23: and illustrate how it may provide information to feed the trust process in online news stories. As a case study
column24: we illustrate the approach using a Knowledge Graph created with such claims
column25: which can be queried in order to better understand the existing relations between agents in the Political System in Brazil. In order to use claims in this Knowledge Graph
column26: users will typically require provenance information to make trust judgements about them.""

column1: Faustini P., Ferreira Covoes T.,"Fake news detection using one-class classification",2019,"Proceedings - 2019 Brazilian Conference on Intelligent Systems, BRACIS 2019",1,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85077084653&doi=10.1109%2fBRACIS.2019.00109&partnerID=40&md5=93c6d586ba8f13c52d4d2ada100eefbf","Center of Mathematics, Computing and Cognition (CMCC), Universidade Federal Do ABC (UFABC), Santo André, Brazil, Brazil","Faustini, P., Center of Mathematics, Computing and Cognition (CMCC), Universidade Federal Do ABC (UFABC), Santo André, Brazil, Brazil;" Ferreira Covoes
column9: Fake news have attracted attention of general public because of the influence they can exert on important activities of society
column10: such as elections. Efforts have been made to detect them
column11: but usually they rely on human labour fact-checking
column12: what can be costly and time consuming. Computational approaches have typically relied on supervised learning models
column13: in which a model is trained based on fake and true news samples. Such approach allows a large amount of news to be classified in a short time
column14: but it demands datasets labelled with positive and negative instances. Our work proposes to detect fake news by training a model with only fake samples in the training dataset
column15: through One-Class Classification (OCC). We compare a novel algorithm
column20: results. The case study is the Brazilian politics scenario starting at the 2018 general elections on Twitter and WhatsApp. These two platforms were a fertile ground to fake news proliferation. We also evaluated the models over another available dataset from literature. To the best of our knowledge
column21: this is the first paper to identify fake news using an OCC approach and also the first one to provide Portuguese-based WhatsApp and Twitter datasets with fake news. © 2019 IEEE.""

column1: Verma P.K., Agrawal P.,"Study and Detection of Fake News: P2C2-Based Machine Learning Approach",2021,"Advances in Intelligent Systems and Computing",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85092148381&doi=10.1007%2f978-981-15-5619-7_18&partnerID=40&md5=cb32d5791ac638b8667c8dbe97e92bbe","GLA University, Mathura, India; Lovely Professional University
column21: News is the most important and sensitive piece of information which affects the society nowadays. In the current scenario
column22: there are two ways to propagate news all over the world"; first one is the traditional way
column24: newspaper and second is electronic media like social media websites. Electronic media is the most popular medium these days because it helps to propagate news to huge audience in few seconds. Besides these benefits of electronic media
column27: “spreading the Fake News”. Fake news is the most common problem these days. Even big companies like Twitter
column29: etc. are facing fake news problems. Several researchers are working in these big companies to solve this problem. Fake news can be defined as the news story that is not true. In some specific words
column30: we can say that news is fake if any news agency declares a piece of news deliberately written as false and it is also verifiably as false. This paper focuses on some key characteristics of fake news and how it is affecting the society nowadays. It also includes various key viewpoints which are useful to categorize whether the news is fake or not. At last
column31: this paper discussed some key challenges and future directions that help in increasing accuracy in detection of fake news on the basis of P2C2 (Propagation
column33: Comprehension & Credibility) approach having two phases: Detection and Verification. This paper helps readers in two ways (i) Newcomer can easily get the basic knowledge and impact of fake news;" (ii) They can get knowledge of different perspectives of fake news which are helpful in the detection process. © 2021

column19: With the development of media including newspaper written by robots and many unreliable sources
column20: it's getting hard to distinguish whether the news is true or not. In this paper
column21: we shall present a novel fake news detection model
column22: FaNDeR(Fake News Detection model using media Reliability) which can efficiently classify the level of truth for the news in the question answering system based on modified CNN deep learning model. Our model reflects the reliability of various medias by training with the input dataset which contains the truthfulness of each media as well as that of the proposition. Our model is designed for higher accuracy with media dataset in terms of data augmentation
column23: batch size control and model modification. We shall show that our model has higher accuracy over statistical approach by reflecting the tendency of truth level for each media through the training of the dataset collected so far. © 2018 IEEE.""

column1: Alba-Juez L., Mackenzie J.L.,"Emotion, lies, and “bullshit” in journalistic discourse: The case of fake news [Emoción, mentiras y “bullshit” en el discurso periodístico: El caso de las noticias falsas/falseadas o “fake news”]",2019,"Iberica",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85078280095&partnerID=40&md5=4f897677eda5d72a69d2122a1f7477e6","UNED, Spain;" VU Amsterdam
column14: Emotion is part and parcel of all kinds of human experience and as such plays an important role in all discourse types
column15: including professional discourse. In the 21st century more than ever
column16: the proper channeling and expression of our emotions at the workplace has come to be considered a sign of emotional intelligence
column19: persuasion can also be used as a weapon to lie and manipulate people’s emotions. Meibauer (2018) notes that lying and deception play an important role in business and trade
column20: and this is obviously the case in the business of fake news. In this article we analyze the genre of fake news within professional journalistic discourse. We carry out a qualitative sociopragmatic analysis of samples of political and scientific fake news in English
column21: and show how this kind of journalism aims at manipulating readers’ emotions not only through the use of prototypical lies (i.e. assertions whose content the speaker believes to be false
column22: uttered with the intention of deceiving the hearer)
column23: but mainly by means of complex discourse-pragmatic strategies such as the skillful manipulation of the three chief evaluative subsystems
column27: the triggering of false inferences and the display of misleading images
column28: thus playing with the scalarity of lying. This in turn leads us to some important conclusions showing that the fact that the linguistic expression of falsity can be scalar is intimately connected with the concepts of “bullshit” (Frankfurt
column30: 2004): a good story that somehow touches readers’ emotions
column33: because the readers choose to accept as true what makes them “feel good”.emotion

column31: We investigated the differential diffusion of all of the verified true and false news stories distributed on Twitter from 2006 to 2017. The data comprise ~126

column35: and more broadly than the truth in all categories of information
column36: and the effects were more pronounced for false political news than for false news about terrorism
column40: or financial information. We found that false news was more novel than true news
column41: which suggests that people were more likely to share novel information. Whereas false stories inspired fear
column47: and trust. Contrary to conventional wisdom
column48: robots accelerated the spread of true and false news at the same rate
column49: implying that false news spreads more than the truth because humans
column51: are more likely to spread it. © 2017 The Authors.""

column1: Chaiehloudj W.,"Fake news and competition law: Reflections based on the cases of Facebook and google [Fake news et droit de la concurrence: Réflexions au prisme des cas Facebook et Google]",2018,"Revue Internationale de Droit Economique",1,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85049799623&doi=10.3917%2fride.321.0017&partnerID=40&md5=e12aeed4361f76c71c380fe0c52cc9f3","ATER à Aix-Marseille Université, France","Chaiehloudj, W., ATER à Aix-Marseille Université, France","Fake news covers a very wide spectrum of ""false news"" or ""false information."" It can be intentional or unintentional, emanating from companies or persons using social networks, or, more broadly, on the internet. Fake news can also appear to be true information but that, deliberately decontextualized, becomes deceptive for the recipients. A priori, fake news is not a competition issue. Nonetheless, fake news could in the future infringe competition rules. It could provide a support base for collusive behavior or, in abusive fashion, reinforce the market power of a dominant company. This prospective study proposes to reflect on this topic and to examine whether competition law possesses the necessary tools to counteract potentially anti-competitive practices. © 2018Revue Internationale de Droit Economique.","Abuse of dominance; Algorithm; Big data; Cartel; Competition law; Digital economy; Fake news; Online advertising;" Personal data""

column1: Rodríguez-Ferrándiz R.,"Post-truth and fake news in political communication: A brief genealogy [Posverdad y fake news en comunicación política: Breve genealogía]",2019,"Profesional de la Informacion",2,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85077948766&doi=10.3145%2fepi.2019.may.14&partnerID=40&md5=72d19cb8dfb62389dbf733ba94eb1555","Universidad de Alicante, Departamento de Comunicación y Psicología Social, Avda. de San Vicente, s/n, Alicante, 03080, Spain","Rodríguez-Ferrándiz, R., Universidad de Alicante, Departamento de Comunicación y Psicología Social, Avda. de San Vicente, s/n, Alicante, 03080, Spain","The article exposes post-truth politics and fake news meaning, origin and precedents. Recent cases of both expressions are described and discussed. We offer and value the interpretations that have been given of these phenomena, around a double axis: those that demonstrate its continuity (as novel incarnations of demagogy, propaganda or disinformation) as opposed to those that emphasize its novelty, and those that put the accent on technology versus those that speak of a true epistemological transformation or discover the psychological motivations that subtend them. Finally, corrective measures are summarized and discussed: regulation or self-regulation of contents, fact-checking, monitoring of search algorithms and digital literacy programs. © 2019, El Profesional de la Informacion. All rights reserved.","Concepts; Definitions; Demagogy; Facebook; Fact checking; Fake news; Filter bubble; Human behavior; Media; Political communication; Post-truth; Review; Social media; Social networking sites;" Society""

column1: Galeotti A.E.,"Believing fake news",2019,"Post-Truth, Philosophy and Law",1,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85069843387&doi=10.4324%2f9780429450778-6&partnerID=40&md5=fef8a8902fffcfbaca54a6e0a99ca7f6","The Department of Humanities, The University of Eastern Piedmont, Vercelli, Italy","Galeotti, A.E., The Department of Humanities, The University of Eastern Piedmont, Vercelli, Italy","In this chapter, I want to face the phenomenon of fake news by raising two questions, the first concerning the nature of fake news; the second addressing the issue from the viewpoint of the recipient or consumer. More specifically
column2: I want to ask on the basis of which cognitive traps and mechanisms
column3: cognizers end up believing fake news at a higher and faster rate than true news. In the first section of the chapter I shall thus take up the discussion on what fake news is and see whether a specific account can be provided that mark it specifically off compared to traditional forms of public deception. The relevant deception here is public for fake news typically affects large audiences and constitutes a public concern for a healthy democracy. In the second section of the chapter
column4: I shall try to map the cognitive and motivational traps making people victims of this form of disinformation and deception. Finally
column6: I shall take up the discussion about possible remedies
column7: focusing on the ones directed at improving individual epistemic responses to fake news exposure. I shall not deal with the controversial institutional remedies
column9: I shall try to connect the findings in cognitive psychology and in epistemology with the studies of new media communications and see whether some hints for counteracting the effect of fake news can be found. © 2019 selection and editorial matter

column1: Bago B., Rand D.G., Pennycook G.,"Fake news, fast and slow: Deliberation reduces belief in false (but not true) news headlines",2020,"Journal of Experimental Psychology: General",5,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85078609227&doi=10.1037%2fxge0000729&partnerID=40&md5=10a33acf5b5fe1db5aac8e5c246f10ae","University of Toulouse Capitole, France; Massachusetts Institute of Technology
column14: What role does deliberation play in susceptibility to political misinformation and """"fake news""""? The Motivated System 2 Reasoning (MS2R) account posits that deliberation causes people to fall for fake news
column15: because reasoning facilitates identity-protective cognition and is therefore used to rationalize content that is consistent with one's political ideology. The classical account of reasoning instead posits that people ineffectively discern between true and false news headlines when they fail to deliberate (and instead rely on intuition). To distinguish between these competing accounts
column16: we investigated the causal effect of reasoning on media truth discernment using a 2-response paradigm. Participants (N 1
column17: 635 Mechanical Turkers) were presented with a series of headlines. For each
column18: they were first asked to give an initial
column19: intuitive response under time pressure and concurrent working memory load. They were then given an opportunity to rethink their response with no constraints
column20: thereby permitting more deliberation. We also compared these responses to a (deliberative) 1-response baseline condition where participants made a single choice with no constraints. Consistent with the classical account
column21: we found that deliberation corrected intuitive mistakes: Participants believed false headlines (but not true headlines) more in initial responses than in either final responses or the unconstrained 1-response baseline. In contrast-and inconsistent with the Motivated System 2 Reasoning account-we found that political polarization was equivalent across responses. Our data suggest that
column22: in the context of fake news
column23: deliberation facilitates accurate belief formation and not partisan bias. © 2019 American Psychological Association.""

column1: Berthon P., Pehlivan E., Yalcin T., Rabinovich T.,"True, fake and alternative: a topology of news and its implications for brands",2019,"Journal of Product and Brand Management",1,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85068111960&doi=10.1108%2fJPBM-11-2018-2142&partnerID=40&md5=ff26deec99fdb95e56a2aad18cf76ab9","McCallum Graduate School, Bentley University, Waltham, MA, United States; Martin V. Smith School of Business and Economics
column5: United States;" California State University Channel Islands
column17: Martin V. Smith School of Business and Economics
column33: Purpose: Berthon and Pitt (2018) recently highlighted the symbiotic relationship between fake news and brands. This paper aims to draw on semiotics to refine the fake/real news dichotomy to a fourfold typology. Design/methodology/approach: First
column34: the authors turn to semiotics and review Greimas’ (1966) semiotic square. Second
column35: they use this framework to refine the fake/real news dichotomy into a four-fold typology. Third
column36: they illustrate each type with a news report on the topic of climate change. Fourth
column37: they apply this framework to reveal four types of brand: real
column39: empty and ironic. Findings: Given that brand communications are heterogeneous
column40: the authors suggest that the typology can be reconceptualized as dimensions and brands communications decoded accordingly. They conclude by exploring further opportunities offered by the semiotic square for interpretive investigation. Originality/value: The value of the paper lies in the novel use of the semiotic square to shed light on both news and brand communications. © 2019

column1: Seo Y., Jeong C.-S.,"FaGoN: Fake news detection model using grammatic transformation on neural network",2018,"KICSS 2018 - 2018 13th International Conference on Knowledge, Information and Creativity Support Systems, Proceedings",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85078907026&doi=10.1109%2fKICSS45055.2018.8950518&partnerID=40&md5=76d59896a561f8d8588fc2c934e6e68d","Korea University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Seoul, South Korea","Seo, Y., Korea University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Seoul, South Korea;" Jeong
column8: most of fake news are detected and verified by people
column9: which requires a great amount of time and effort. It is difficult to Figure out the truthfulness of the news by machine algorithm because the sentences have various forms. In this paper
column10: we shall present a fast and efficient fake news detection model which can Figure out whether the given proposition is true or not from article by exploiting grammatical transformation based on deep learning. Our model consists of four layers: word embedding layer
column12: matching layer and inference layer. In word embedding layer
column13: the words in proposition are embedded into word vector. In context generation layer
column14: the word vectors enter into LSTM layer and generate context vector. In matching layer
column15: attention vector is generated from the contextual embedding vector in the previous layer computing the weighted sum. Then
column16: the hidden state vector from LSTM layers and attention vector are compared through matching operation generating the sentences which has the same meaning but different forms. In inference layer
column17: our model calculates the similarity between the generated sentences and the sentences in articles
column19: true or false. We shall evaluate our model calculating the perplexity to Figure out whether the generated sentences are grammatically correct. Also
column20: the model is tested by changing the sentence group's size to find the optimal size of the group. By showing the Our model figured out the fake news very well with the test of CNN news dataset getting the right answer. © 2018 IEEE.""

column1: Smelter T.J., Calvillo D.P.,"Pictures and repeated exposure increase perceived accuracy of news headlines",2020,"Applied Cognitive Psychology",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85084444526&doi=10.1002%2facp.3684&partnerID=40&md5=6f9c0ebd2fa7310ece6ebdfcdb6b5cd4","Psychology Department, California State University San Marcos, San Marcos, CA, United States","Smelter, T.J., Psychology Department, California State University San Marcos, San Marcos, CA, United States;" Calvillo
column9: deliberately inaccurate and often biased information that is presented as accurate reporting
column10: is perceived as a serious threat. Recent research on fake news has documented a high general susceptibility to the phenomenon and has focused on investigating potential explanatory factors. The present study examined how features of news headlines affected their perceived accuracy. Across four experiments (total N = 659)
column11: we examined the effects of pictures
column13: and repeated exposure on the perceived accuracy of news headlines. In all experiments
column14: participants received a set of true and false news headlines and rated their accuracy. The presence of pictures and repeated exposure increased perceived accuracy
column15: whereas manipulations of perceptual clarity did not show the predicted effects. The effects of pictures and repeated exposure were similar for true and false headlines. These results demonstrate that accompanying pictures and repeated exposure can affect evaluations of truth of news headlines. © 2020 John Wiley & Sons

column1: Santia G.C., Williams J.R.,"Buzz face: A news veracity dataset with facebook user commentary and egos",2018,"12th International AAAI Conference on Web and Social Media, ICWSM 2018",13,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85050637251&partnerID=40&md5=bd9211a010937ad8aec860f51ca5bb82","Department of Information Science, College of Computing and Informatics, Drexel University, 30 North 33rd Street, Philadelphia, PA  19104, United States","Santia, G.C., Department of Information Science, College of Computing and Informatics, Drexel University, 30 North 33rd Street, Philadelphia, PA  19104, United States;" Williams
column10: Veracity assessment of news and social bot detection have become two of the most pressing issues for social media platforms
column11: yet current gold-standard data are limited. This paper presents a leap forward in the development of a sizeable and feature rich gold-standard dataset. The dataset was built by using a collection of news items posted to Facebook by nine news outlets during September 2016
column12: which were annotated for veracity by BuzzFeed. These articles were refined beyond binary annotation to the four categories: mostly true
column15: and no factual content. Our contribution integrates data on Facebook comments and reactions publicly available on the platform's Graph API
column16: and provides tailored tools for accessing news article web content. The features of the accessed articles include body text
column21: and embedded tweets. Embedded tweets provide a potent possible avenue for expansion across social media platforms. Upon development
column22: this utility yielded over 1.6 million text items
column23: making it over 400 times larger than the current gold-standard. The resulting dataset'BuzzFace'is presently the most extensive created
column24: and allows for more robust machine learning applications to news veracity assessment and social bot detection than ever before. Copyright © 2018
column25: Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (www.aaai.org). All rights reserved.""

column1: Iwuoha V.C.,"‘Fake News’ and ‘Half-truths’ in the Framings of Boko Haram Narrative: Implications on International Counterterrorism Responses [‘Noticias falsas’ y ‘Medias verdades’ en los encuadres de la narrativa de Boko Haram: Implicaciones en las respuestas internacionales contra el terrorismo]",2020,"International Journal of Intelligence, Security, and Public Affairs",,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85090796873&doi=10.1080%2f23800992.2020.1771972&partnerID=40&md5=7ec7ec24e3653be6c4f48c3a54448a6e","Department of Political Science, University of Nigeria, Nsukka, Nigeria","Iwuoha, V.C., Department of Political Science, University of Nigeria, Nsukka, Nigeria","What concerns do official statements, especially government press releases on counterterrorism war against Boko Haram generate for countries outside Nigeria, and what are their counterterrorism responses to such sensitive military information? Nigeria’s official counterterrorism and military statements rarely met its intended objectives of improving military’s public image, applauding government’s counterterrorism efforts, and attracting international counterterrorism support. It, however, depicted government’s tendency in the use of ‘fake news’ and ‘half-truths’ in blanketing loopholes in its counterterrorism war against Boko Haram. This article argues that government’s adoption of ‘fake news’ and false statements, as ‘technology of security governance,’ in the framings of Boko Haram’s narrative and counterterrorism analysis is implicated in the shrinkage of international counterterrorism assistance (i.e. troop contribution, intelligence support, military financing, weapons supply, military trainings, cyber-security support, etc.), and consequently the intractability of Boko Haram insurgency. I elicit primary data from top military officers. I conclude by reflecting on a broad counterinsurgency information analysis model that will encompass new techniques for exclusive investigative inquiry in sorting out pieces of false information that are intricately mixed up in true statements. © 2020 Taylor & Francis.","Boko Haram; counterterrorism; cyber-security; Fake news; military and security; Nigeria;" post-truth""

column1: Buschman J.,"Good news, bad news, and fake news: Going beyond political literacy to democracy and libraries",2019,"Journal of Documentation",9,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85057134196&doi=10.1108%2fJD-05-2018-0074&partnerID=40&md5=49a98d13923d342c6ea1d26cc20d4c90","Seton Hall University, South Orange, NJ, United States","Buschman, J., Seton Hall University, South Orange, NJ, United States","Purpose: Library and Information Science (LIS) has seen an explosion of responses to fake news in the aftermath of the 2016 US election, political in nature, eschewing “neutrality” supporting democracy. The purpose of this paper is to trace the definition of fake news, the challenges, the roots of recent respondes to fake news, notes that the theoretical understanding of democracy must keep pace with these efforts. Design/methodology/approach: Conceptual analysis of the LIS literature concerning fake news and its underlying themes; unpacking of actually existing democracy
column2: re-linked to LIS practices. Findings: Democracy does not require a space cleared of distorting claims but spaces suited to grappling with them
column3: a call to address fake news
column4: and not simply a matter of clearing up information sources;" librarians should prepared to engage at the next level. Libraries stand for the proposition that there is more-true information which is worth accessing
column7: and for inclusion. Whether explicitly political or not
column8: the imaginative uses to which libraries are put do enrich civil society and the public sphere. Libraries help to counter fake news both through specific educative actions aimed at it and as broadly educative institutions with a coherent notion of their relationship to informational discernment in democracy. Originality/value: LIS discourse on fake news has value
column10: but assumes a set of traditional relationships between informing
column11: libraries and democracy. This paper goes at both the lesser role of informing and highlights the (arguably) greater social role of libraries in democratic society. © 2019

column1: Deepika N., Guruprasad N.,"Detecting text anomalies in social networks using different machine learning algorithms",2019,"International Journal of Engineering and Advanced Technology",1,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85072069320&doi=10.35940%2fijeat.F9253.088619&partnerID=40&md5=2f96c9d60ed3f714699527975ec4105d","Department of CSE, VTUKarnataka, India;" Department of CSE
column17: Today information is very powerful tool and this information is highly unreliable and wrong information can be very manipulative. It can cause harm to life as well. This in today’s world is called fake news or yellow journalism. Media sometime tries to manipulate and take advantage of innocent viewers by making them believe something that is not real. This has come to publicity recently due to the US presidential election and how media was used to operate the results of the election. Sometime news channel want to garner attention hence they intentionally put this news and as it is our human tendency we always go for the bad apple and this spreads faster than a normal true news would have. The news source got what they needed but they did so by making a fool out of millions of people. So how do we make this problem go away? We train different machine learning algorithms to recognize between fake and real and we know that a machine cannot be subjective and its decision will always be fair and mathematical. Hence in this project we create an API which can tell whether given news is real or fake based of our training data. © BEIESP.""

column1: Rath B., Gao W., Srivastava J.,"Evaluating vulnerability to fake news in social networks: A community health assessment model",2019,"Proceedings of the 2019 IEEE/ACM International Conference on Advances in Social Networks Analysis and Mining, ASONAM 2019",1,"https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85078820401&doi=10.1145%2f3341161.3342920&partnerID=40&md5=047ad81d76631c66bf2d75aa59da3ca5","Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, University of Minnesota, Twin Cities, MN, United States;" School of Information Management
column7: Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering
column18: Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering
column23: Understanding the spread of false information in social networks has gained a lot of recent attention. In this paper
column24: we explore the role community structures play in determining how people get exposed to fake news. Inspired by approaches in epidemiology
column25: we propose a novel Community Health Assessment model
column26: whose goal is to understand the vulnerability of communities to fake news spread. We define the concepts of neighbor
column27: boundary and core nodes of a community and propose appropriate metrics to quantify the vulnerability of nodes (individual-level) and communities (group-level) to spreading fake news. We evaluate our model on communities identified using three popular community detection algorithms for twelve real-world news spreading networks collected from Twitter. Experimental results show that the proposed metrics perform significantly better on the fake news spreading networks than on the true news
column28: indicating that our community health assessment model is effective. © 2019 Association for Computing Machinery.""
